clusters.title: My schoolmates mocked me for being a UPF-free, ‘weird lunchbox’ kid. Turns out my mum was right all along
clusters.neutral_headline: My schoolmates mocked me for being a UPF-free, ‘weird lunchbox’ kid. Turns out my mum was right all along: In the 90s my mum embarrassed me with her rejection of ultra-processed foods – but the growing body of evidence about them is vindicating herA very specific childhood experience arose from being a “weird-lunchbox kid” growing up in the 90s with a food-conscious mother. It was the sense of palpitating trepidation felt when opening your school lunchbox, knowing that what lay within was going to be seen as “weird” in comparison with the sliced-white-bread-plastic-ham sandwiches, cheesy Wotsits and Club biscuits everyone else was gobbling.What’s that?” your classmate would ask, their nose wrinkling as they took in yesterday’s veggie curry, crumbling homemade falafel or – my mother’s speciality – a “deconstructed sandwich” of doorstop-thick fresh bread, filling of some kind (often cucumber) and attendant crumbs floating freely in the bag. (Why bother assembling at all?, my father asked once, when you could simply throw in all the elements and shake?)Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett is a Guardian columnist Continue reading

items.title: My schoolmates mocked me for being a UPF-free, ‘weird lunchbox’ kid. Turns out my mum was right all along

(Why bother assembling at all?, my father asked once, when you could simply throw in all the elements and shake?)Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett is a Guardian columnist Continue reading...

(Why bother assembling at all?, my father asked once, when you could simply throw in all the elements and shake?)Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett is a Guardian columnist Continue reading...

ai_summary: The author reflects on childhood experiences with a food-conscious mother.
The author's lunchbox was considered "weird" compared to classmates' lunches.
The author's mother rejected ultra-processed foods in the 1990s.
Growing evidence supports the author's mother's food choices.
The article is a personal reflection on food and childhood.

clusters.title: Dangerous shortage of medics threatens safe patient care in England, top GP says
clusters.neutral_headline: Dangerous shortage of medics threatens safe patient care in England, top GP says: Exclusive: Royal College of GPs chair says surgeries desperate to hire more doctors but lack funding to do soGPs can no longer guarantee safe care for millions of patients because of a dangerous shortage of medics, Britain’s top family doctor has said.Prof Kamila Hawthorne, the chair of the Royal College of GPs (RCGP), said surgeries were desperate to hire more doctors to meet soaring demand for care but could not afford to do so because of a lack of core funding. Continue reading

Continue reading...

Continue reading...

GPs cannot guarantee safe care for millions of patients.
Demand for care is increasing, exacerbating the problem.

clusters.title: Two UK clinical trials to assess impact of puberty blockers in young people
clusters.neutral_headline: Two UK clinical trials to assess impact of puberty blockers in young people: Multi-year studies announced after Cass review found ‘insufficient evidence’ about effects on children with gender dysphoriaTwo studies to investigate the impact of puberty blockers in young people with gender incongruence have been announced by researchers in the UK after an expert view said gender medicine was “built on shaky foundations”.Puberty blockers were originally used to treat early onset puberty in children but have also been used off-label in children with gender dysphoria or incongruence. Continue reading

items.title: Two UK clinical trials to assess impact of puberty blockers in young people

Continue reading...
items.content: Multi-year studies announced after Cass review found ‘insufficient evidence’ about effects on children with gender dysphoriaTwo studies to investigate the impact of puberty blockers in young people with gender incongruence have been announced by researchers in the UK after an expert view said gender medicine was “built on shaky foundations”.Puberty blockers were originally used to treat early onset puberty in children but have also been used off-label in children with gender dysphoria or incongruence. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Two UK clinical trials will assess puberty blockers' impact.
The studies follow the Cass review findings.
The review found insufficient evidence on effects.
The trials will focus on young people with gender incongruence.
Puberty blockers were used off-label for gender dysphoria.

clusters.title: Influencers made millions pushing ‘wild’ births – now the Free Birth Society is linked to baby deaths around the world
clusters.neutral_headline: Influencers made millions pushing ‘wild’ births – now the Free Birth Society is linked to baby deaths around the world: A year-long investigation reveals how mothers lost children after being radicalised by uplifting podcast tales of births without midwives or doctorsAs Esau Lopez was asphyxiated for the first 17 minutes of his life on Earth, the atmosphere in the room remained serene, even ecstatic. Acoustic music crooned from a speaker in a modest two-bedroom apartment in a suburb of Pennsylvania. “You are a queen,” murmured one of three friends in the room.Only Esau’s mother, Gabrielle Lopez, felt something was wrong. She was pushing hard, but her son would not be born. “Can you help [him] out?” she asked, as Esau crowned. “Baby is coming,” the friend replied. Four minutes later, Lopez asked again, “Can you grab [him]?” Another friend murmured, “Baby is safe.” Six minutes passed. Again, Lopez asked, “Can you grab [him]?” Continue reading

Four minutes later, Lopez asked again, “Can you grab [him]?” Another friend murmured, “Baby is safe.” Six minutes passed. Again, Lopez asked, “Can you grab [him]?” Continue reading...

The Free Birth Society is under scrutiny.

Mothers lost children after being influenced by podcasts.
The article details a specific case of a baby's death.

clusters.title: Control of HIV, TB and malaria at risk after global health fund donations fall
clusters.neutral_headline: Global Fund faces funding shortfall for health initiatives

items.title: Control of HIV, TB and malaria at risk after global health fund donations fall
items.standfirst: World leaders pledge just over $11bn, short of the $18bn experts say is needed to stay on track to tackle challengesControl of the deadly infectious diseases HIV, tuberculosis and malaria “hangs in the balance” after a shortfall in donations to a leading global health fund, advocates have warned.Only $11.3bn of the Global Fund to Fight Aids, TB and Malaria’s $18bn (£14bn) targeted budget for 2026 to 2028 has been confirmed so far. Continue reading...
items.content: World leaders pledge just over $11bn, short of the $18bn experts say is needed to stay on track to tackle challengesControl of the deadly infectious diseases HIV, tuberculosis and malaria “hangs in the balance” after a shortfall in donations to a leading global health fund, advocates have warned.Only $11.3bn of the Global Fund to Fight Aids, TB and Malaria’s $18bn (£14bn) targeted budget for 2026 to 2028 has been confirmed so far. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Global Fund needs $18 billion to fight HIV, TB, and malaria by 2028.
Only $11.3 billion has been pledged for the 2026-2028 period.
Advocates warn that control of these diseases is now at risk.
The shortfall could impact efforts to tackle these infectious diseases.
The Global Fund aims to support programs in low and middle-income countries.

clusters.title: Coroners’ prevention of future deaths reports should be legally enforced | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Coroners' reports on deaths should be legally enforced

items.title: Coroners’ prevention of future deaths reports should be legally enforced | Letters
items.standfirst: Christine and Francis Saunders, who lost their beloved daughter Juliet, respond to the news that advice on maternal deaths in England and Wales has been routinely ignoredThank you for your article on how coroners’ prevention of future deaths (PFD) reports are being routinely ignored (Coroners’ advice on maternal deaths in England and Wales routinely ignored, study finds, 19 November).Experience has shown us that a coroner’s PFD report is issued in response to serious systemic failings and a trust’s inaction to prevent future tragedies. Tolerating poor care and refusing to learn seem to be shared features of health scandals, including the treatment of people with learning disabilities, such as our own beloved daughter, Juliet Saunders, who died aged 25. Continue reading...
items.content: Christine and Francis Saunders, who lost their beloved daughter Juliet, respond to the news that advice on maternal deaths in England and Wales has been routinely ignoredThank you for your article on how coroners’ prevention of future deaths (PFD) reports are being routinely ignored (Coroners’ advice on maternal deaths in England and Wales routinely ignored, study finds, 19 November).Experience has shown us that a coroner’s PFD report is issued in response to serious systemic failings and a trust’s inaction to prevent future tragedies. Tolerating poor care and refusing to learn seem to be shared features of health scandals, including the treatment of people with learning disabilities, such as our own beloved daughter, Juliet Saunders, who died aged 25. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Coroners' reports on preventing future deaths are often ignored.
A study found that advice on maternal deaths is routinely disregarded.
The article discusses systemic failings in healthcare.
The authors share their experience of losing their daughter.
They believe that inaction leads to repeated tragedies.

Continue reading...

Continue reading...

Job stress and childcare are significant factors.
The government wants to move services to health centers.
The health secretary aims to make it easier to see a doctor.

clusters.title: We know ultra-processed foods are bad for you – but can you spot them? Take our quiz
clusters.neutral_headline: Ultra-processed foods: Can you identify them?

items.title: We know ultra-processed foods are bad for you – but can you spot them? Take our quiz
items.standfirst: Test your knowledge in eight questions to prove you know your onions from your emulsifiersA major global report released this week linked ultra-processed foods to harm in every major human organ. For people in the US, the UK and Australia, these foods make up more than half the calories they consume each day.But it’s not always easy to tell which foods are ultra-processed.Group one: unprocessed or minimally processed foods including whole fruits and vegetables, milk, oats and rice.Group two: processed basic ingredients used in cooking including salt, sugar and vegetable oils.Group three: processed foods made by adding items from groups one and two. Includes canned legumes, bread and cheese.Group four: ultra-processed foods which are commercial products made from extracts of foods, often with added chemicals, flavours and other ingredients you wouldn’t find in a home kitchen.With thanks to Dr Priscila Machado from the Institute for Physical Activity and Nutrition at Deakin University for checking this quiz for accuracy Continue reading...
items.content: Test your knowledge in eight questions to prove you know your onions from your emulsifiersA major global report released this week linked ultra-processed foods to harm in every major human organ. For people in the US, the UK and Australia, these foods make up more than half the calories they consume each day.But it’s not always easy to tell which foods are ultra-processed.Group one: unprocessed or minimally processed foods including whole fruits and vegetables, milk, oats and rice.Group two: processed basic ingredients used in cooking including salt, sugar and vegetable oils.Group three: processed foods made by adding items from groups one and two. Includes canned legumes, bread and cheese.Group four: ultra-processed foods which are commercial products made from extracts of foods, often with added chemicals, flavours and other ingredients you wouldn’t find in a home kitchen.With thanks to Dr Priscila Machado from the Institute for Physical Activity and Nutrition at Deakin University for checking this quiz for accuracy Continue reading...

ai_summary: A report linked ultra-processed foods to harm in major organs.
These foods make up over half the calories in some diets.
The quiz tests knowledge of food processing levels.
Group one includes unprocessed foods like fruits and vegetables.
Group four includes ultra-processed foods with added chemicals.

clusters.title: Labour MPs urge Reeves to drop private finance plans for NHS buildings

items.title: Labour MPs urge Reeves to drop private finance plans for NHS buildings
items.standfirst: Chancellor told PFI-style schemes familiar from New Labour era are ‘fiscal illusion’ offering no value for moneyRachel Reeves has been urged by 40 Labour MPs to drop plans to fund NHS buildings with private finance initiatives (PFI) that would saddle the health service with debt.The Labour MPs, including Cat Eccles, Clive Lewis and Rebecca Long-Bailey, pressed the chancellor to commit to investment in the NHS without the use of private capital and warned that a return to the New Labour era of private funding for public projects would be damaging for trust in the government. Continue reading...

Continue reading...
